Data Types

Now that you know how to create variables and constants, it‚Äôs time to learn what kinds of values they can store. These are called data types.

Ferret comes with a set of built‚Äëin types that let you work with numbers, text, true/false values, and more.

Primitive Types

Section titled ‚ÄúPrimitive Types‚Äù

Primitive types are the simplest kinds of data. Internally they are just numbers.

Integer Types

Section titled ‚ÄúInteger Types‚Äù

These types store whole numbers.

TypeSizeRangeDescription
i3232‚Äëbit-2¬≥¬π to 2¬≥¬π‚Äë1Standard integer
i6464‚Äëbit-2‚Å∂¬≥ to 2‚Å∂¬≥‚Äë1Bigger integer
u3232‚Äëbit0 to 2¬≥¬≤‚Äë1Non‚Äënegative integer
u6464‚Äëbit0 to 2‚Å∂‚Å¥‚Äë1Bigger non‚Äënegative integer

Now if you are confused about the i and u prefixes, i stands for signed integers (can be negative) and u stands for unsigned integers (non-negative only). And the numbers 32 and 64 stand for the number of bits used to store the value. Other languages may use different names for these types, but the concepts are the same. So when you see i32, think of it as a 32-bit signed integer.

Now remember the := operator you learned about in the Variables & Constants section? It is used for declaring variables and constants with type inference. Type inference means Ferret can automatically figure out the type based on the value you provide. But if you want to explicitly specify the type, you can do so using a colon : followed by the type name.

Floating‚ÄëPoint Types

Section titled ‚ÄúFloating‚ÄëPoint Types‚Äù

These types store numbers with decimal points. Think of them as numbers that can have fractional parts.

TypeSizePrecisionDescription
f3232‚Äëbit~7 digitsSingle precision float
f6464‚Äëbit~15 digitsDouble precision (default)

The f stands for floating-point, and the numbers 32 and 64 represent the bits used to store the value. The bigger the number, the more precise your decimal calculations will be.

When you write a number with a decimal point without specifying a type, Ferret automatically uses f64 because it gives you better precision.

String Type

Section titled ‚ÄúString Type‚Äù

Strings store text‚Äîanything from single letters to entire paragraphs. In Ferret, strings are represented by the str type.

You create strings by wrapping text in double quotes ".

Strings are one of the most common types you‚Äôll work with. They‚Äôre perfect for storing names, messages, file paths, and any other text data.

Boolean Type

Section titled ‚ÄúBoolean Type‚Äù

Booleans represent yes/no, on/off, or true/false values. There are only two possible values: true and false.

The type name is bool, and booleans are essential for making decisions in your code.

You‚Äôll use booleans constantly when writing conditions, like ‚Äúif the user is logged in‚Äù or ‚Äúwhile the game is running.‚Äù

Character Type

Section titled ‚ÄúCharacter Type‚Äù

A character represents a single letter, symbol, or emoji. Unlike strings that can hold multiple characters, the byte type holds exactly one character. It is called byte because it typically uses one byte (8 bits) of memory to store the value. Internally byte and u8 are the same.

Characters are created using single quotes ' instead of double quotes.

Think of a byte as a single building block, while a str (string) is like a sequence of these blocks.

Compound Types

Section titled ‚ÄúCompound Types‚Äù

Compound types are built by combining other types together. They let you group related data.

Arrays

Section titled ‚ÄúArrays‚Äù

Arrays are collections that store multiple values of the same type in a specific order. Think of them as numbered containers where each slot holds one value.

There are two kinds of arrays in Ferret:

Dynamic arrays can grow or shrink:

Notice the [] before the type‚Äîthis means ‚Äúan array of‚Äù that type.

Fixed-size arrays have a set number of elements:

The number in brackets [7] tells you exactly how many items the array holds. This can‚Äôt change after you create it.

Optional Types

Section titled ‚ÄúOptional Types‚Äù

Sometimes you need to represent ‚ÄúI might have a value, or I might not.‚Äù That‚Äôs what optional types do.

You make any type optional by adding a question mark ? after it. An optional type can hold either a real value or none (which means ‚Äúno value‚Äù).

Optional types help prevent bugs. Instead of crashing when something is missing, Ferret forces you to check if a value exists before using it.

This is much safer than many other languages where missing values can cause crashes!

Custom Types

Section titled ‚ÄúCustom Types‚Äù

Type Aliases

Section titled ‚ÄúType Aliases‚Äù

Sometimes you want to give a type a more meaningful name for your specific use case. Type aliases let you create a new name for an existing type.

Think of it like giving someone a nickname‚Äîthe person is the same, but the name helps clarify their role in a specific context.

This makes your code more readable. When you see UserId, you immediately know it‚Äôs an ID for a user, not just any random number. The underlying type is still i64, but the name gives it meaning.

Type Inference

Section titled ‚ÄúType Inference‚Äù

Here‚Äôs some good news: you don‚Äôt always have to write out the type! When you use the := operator (remember the walrus from the Variables lesson?), Ferret is smart enough to figure out the type from the value you provide.

Type inference makes your code cleaner and faster to write, while still keeping all the safety benefits of having types.

You can always write the type explicitly if you want to be more specific:

Type Conversion

Section titled ‚ÄúType Conversion‚Äù

Sometimes you need to convert a value from one type to another. Ferret requires you to do this explicitly‚Äîit won‚Äôt do it automatically behind your back.

Casting Between Number Types

Section titled ‚ÄúCasting Between Number Types‚Äù

Use the as keyword to convert between number types:

Warning: Converting from floating-point to integer drops the decimal part‚Äîit doesn‚Äôt round!

Converting To and From Strings

Section titled ‚ÄúConverting To and From Strings‚Äù

Numbers can be turned into strings using .to_string():

Converting strings to numbers returns an optional type because the conversion might fail:

Summary

Section titled ‚ÄúSummary‚Äù

You‚Äôve learned about Ferret‚Äôs type system! Here‚Äôs what we covered:

  • Primitive types: Integers (i32, i64, u32, u64), floats (f32, f64), strings (str), booleans (bool), and characters (byte)
  • Compound types: Arrays that hold multiple values
  • Optional types: Types that can be a value or none
  • Type aliases: Custom names for existing types
  • Type inference: Letting Ferret figure out types automatically
  • Type conversion: Explicitly changing between types

Next Steps

Section titled ‚ÄúNext Steps‚Äù

Now that you know about types, you‚Äôre ready to learn what you can do with them:

  • Learn about Operators ‚Äî Do math, compare values, and more
  • Explore Optional Types in depth ‚Äî Master safe handling of missing values
  • Understand Structs ‚Äî Create your own custom types
